사 - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology 1

사삭삮삯산삱삲
삳살삵삶삷삸삹
삺삻삼삽삾삿샀
상샂샃샄샅샆샇
삐 ←→ 새

Syllable

사 • (sa)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ㅅ and ㅏ.

Etymology 2

Korean reading of various Chinese characters.

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[sʰa̠]
  • Phonetic Hangul[사]
Revised Romanization? sa
Revised Romanization (translit.)? sa
McCune–Reischauer? sa
Yale Romanization? sa

Noun

사 • (sa) (hanja 社)

  1. company

사 • (sa) (hanja 死)

  1. death

Numeral

사 • (sa) (hanja 四)

  1. (Sino-Korean numbers, cardinal) four
  2. (ordinal) fourth
Usage notes
In Modern Korean, numbers are almost always written in Arabic numerals.
사 means “fourth” if it is directly put before a noun other than modern units.
사 층: fourth floor
네 층: four floors
사 팀: Team 4
네 팀: four teams

Suffix

—사 • (-sa) (hanja 史)

  1. history

Syllable

사 • (sa)

수 - Wiktionary

Korean

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[sʰu]
  • Phonetic Hangul[수]
Revised Romanization? su
Revised Romanization (translit.)? su
McCune–Reischauer? su
Yale Romanization? swu

Etymology 1

수숙숚숛순숝숞
숟술숡숢숣숤숥
숦숧숨숩숪숫숬
숭숮숯숰숱숲숳
쇼 ←→ 숴

Syllable

수 • (su)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ㅅ and ㅜ.

Etymology 2

Of native Korean origin.

Noun

수 • (su)

  1. way, means, possibility
  2. male (non-human)

Usage notes

After a future determiner and before, 수 (su, “possibility”) with a form of 있다 (itda, “to exist”) or 없다 (eopda, “not to exist”) may translate as a form of “can” or “cannot”, respectively:

  • 마감기한을 맞출 수 있어요.
    Magamgihaneul matchul su isseoyo.
    I can meet the deadline.
  • 갈 수가 없습니다.
    Gal suga eopseumnida.
    [I] cannot go. (Literally, "The future going possibility does not exist.")

Antonyms

  • (male): 암 (am, “female (non-human)”)

Etymology 3

Korean reading of various Chinese characters.

Noun

수 • (su) (hanja 數)

  1. number
    • 수를 세다 ― sureul seda ― to count (the number of)

수 • (su) (hanja 水)

  1. water
  2. river
  3. (figuratively) north; winter; black

Abbreviation

수 • (su) (hanja 水)

  1. Abbreviation of 수요일 (suyoil): Wednesday
Retrieved from "https://en.wiktionary.org/w/index.php?title=수&oldid=49265631"

시 - Wiktionary

Korean

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[ɕʰi]
  • Phonetic Hangul[시]
Revised Romanization? si
Revised Romanization (translit.)? si
McCune–Reischauer? si
Yale Romanization? si

Etymology 1

시식싞싟신싡싢
싣실싥싦싧싨싩
싪싫심십싮싯싰
싱싲싳싴싵싶싷
싀 ←→ 싸

Syllable

시 • (si)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ㅅ and ㅣ.

Etymology 2

Suffix

—시 • (-si)

  1. honorably, rightly, justly; the honorific suffix applied to verbs and adjectives

Usage notes

The honorific form of verbs expresses the social superiority of the subject of the sentence to the speaker. As applied to adjectives, it expresses the relationship between the modified noun and the speaker.

The honorific form is constructed by appending 시 (si) to the sequential form of a verb or an adjective.

Plain (non-honorific) Sequential Honorific
하다 (hada, "to do") 하니 (hani) 하시다 (hasida, "to do (by someone superior to the speaker)"
가다 (gada, "to go") 가니 (gani) 가시다 (gasida, "to go (by someone superior to the speaker)"
살다 (salda, "to live") 사니 (sani) 사시다 (sasida, "to live (by someone superior to the speaker)"
작다 (jakda, "(to be) small") 작으니 (jageuni) 작으시다 (jageusida, "(for something superior to the speaker) to be small"
곱다 (gopda, "(to be) lovely") 고우니 (gouni) 고우시다 (gousida, "(for someone superior to the speaker) to be lovely"

See also

  • 님 (nim), the honorific suffix for many nouns

Etymology 3

Korean reading of various Chinese characters.

Noun

시 • (si, McCune-Reischauer: shi) (hanja 市)

  1. town, city
    • 시의회는 그 문제가 주민 투표를 거쳐야 할 사안이라고 결정하였다.
      Siuihoeneun geu munjega jumin tupyoreul geochyeoya hal saanirago gyeoljeonghayeotda.
      The city council decided the matter should go to public vote.
  2. (South Korea, government) an administrative region, a division of a province having a population of over 150,000
    (Administrative divisions of South Korea) 리 (ri), 동 (dong), 면 (myeon), 읍 (eup), 구 (gu), 군 (gun), 시 (si), 도 (do)

Noun

시 • (si, McCune-Reischauer: shi) (hanja 詩)

  1. poem, poetry

Noun

시 • (si, McCune-Reischauer: shi) (hanja 時)

  1. time
  2. hour

Noun

시 • (si) (hanja 施)

  1. give, grant, bestow

Noun

시 • (si) (hanja 媤)

  1. husband's family
Retrieved from "https://en.wiktionary.org/w/index.php?title=시&oldid=49268815"

신 - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology 1

시식싞싟신싡싢

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[ɕʰin]
  • Phonetic Hangul[신]
Revised Romanization? sin
Revised Romanization (translit.)? sin
McCune–Reischauer? sin
Yale Romanization? sin

Syllable

신 • (sin)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ㅅ, ㅣ, and ㄴ.

Etymology 2

Sino-Korean word from 神 (“god”)

Noun

신 • (sin, McCune-Reischauer: shin, Yale: sin) (hanja 神)

  1. god, God
  2. spirit, departed soul
    땅이 混沌하고 空虛하며 黑暗이 깊음 위에 있고 하나님의 神은 水面에 運行하시니라
    땅이 혼돈하고 공허하며; 흑암이 깊음 위에 있고. 하나님의 신은 수면에 운행하시니라.     (Korean Bible, 창세기 (Genesis) 1:2)
    Ttang-i hondonhago gongheohamyeo; heugami gipeum wie itgo. Hananimui sineun sumyeone unhaenghasinira.
    And the earth was without form, and void; and darkness was upon the face of the deep. And the Spirit of God moved upon the face of the waters.

Etymology 3

Of native Korean origin.

Noun

신 • (sin, McCune-Reischauer: shin, Yale: sin)

  1. joy, delight, amusement
    관중들은 아주 신이 났었다.
    Gwanjungdeureun aju sini nasseotda.
    The audience was frantic with joy.

Etymology 4

Borrowed from English scene.

Pronunciation

  • Phonetic Hangul[씬]

  1. scene
    감동적인 신이었다.
    Gamdongjeogin sinieotda.
    It was a moving scene.

Etymology 5

Of native Korean origin.

Noun

신 • (sin, McCune-Reischauer: shin, Yale: sin)

  1. footgear, footwear, shoes
    신을 벗고 들어가시오.
    Sineul beotgo deureogasio.
    Do not enter with shoes on.

Etymology 6

Of native Korean origin. attributive of 시다 (sida)

Determiner

신 • (sin, McCune-Reischauer: shin)

  1. sour, acid, tart

에 - Wiktionary

Korean

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[e̞]
  • Phonetic Hangul[에]
Revised Romanization? e
Revised Romanization (translit.)? e
McCune–Reischauer? e
Yale Romanization? ey

Etymology 1

에엑엒엓엔엕엖
엗엘엙엚엛엜엝
엞엟엠엡엢엣엤
엥엦엧엨엩엪엫
어 ←→ 여

Syllable

에 • (e)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ㅇ and ㅔ.

Etymology 2

This entry lacks etymological information. If you are familiar with the origin of this term, please add it to the page per etymology instructions. You can also discuss it at the Etymology scriptorium.
Particularly: “Are there any earlier forms of this attested in MK? And does the spelling suggest an earlier form that might have been a diphthong?”

Particle

에 • (e)

  1. at
  2. to
    어디에 가요?
    Eodie gayo?
    Where are you going to?
Usage notes

에 (e) is only used on nouns denoting inanimate objects. For nouns denoting animate objects (usually people or animals), 한테 (hante), 에게 (ege), or 게 (ge) is used instead.

See also
  • 으로 (euro) / 로 (ro)

Etymology 2

Of native Korean origin.

Adverb

우 • (u)

  1. suddenly

Noun

우 • (u)

  1. the name of the hangeul vowel ㅜ (u)
  2. (North Korea) above; top
    • 2004 October 10, "구름우에 솟은 《왕》들의 집-13개의 분교" (The House of "Kings", Soaring Above the Clouds), KCNA[1]:

Suffix

  1. a suffix deriving a causative verb.

Etymology 4

Of native Korean origin.

Alternative forms

  • 수 (su)

Suffix

—우 • (-u)

  1. one of the middle style (하오체) declarative, interrogative, and imperative endings, often used by senior women to higher but familiar women.
    • 언니는 빨간 날에 어디 가시우? (Eonnineun ppalgan nare eodi gasiu?, “Where are you going on the holiday?”)

Usage notes

This is used after a vowel, or the consonant ㄹ (l) in which case the ㄹ (l) falls out. After a consonant other than ㄹ (l), 수 (su) is used instead.

은 - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology 1

으윽윾윿은읁읂
읃을읅읆읇읈읉
읊읋음읍읎읏읐
응읒읓읔읕읖읗
유 ←→ 의

Syllable

은 • (eun)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ㅇ, ㅡ, and ㄴ.

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[ɯn]
  • Phonetic Hangul[은]
Revised Romanization? eun
Revised Romanization (translit.)? eun
McCune–Reischauer? ŭn
Yale Romanization? un

Etymology 2

Of native Korean origin.

Particle

은 • (eun)

  1. 은 (eun) marks the topic of the sentence. The topic of a sentence is not to be confused with the subject of the sentence.
  2. 은 (eun), depending on context, shows contrast with or adds emphasis to the preceding word or phrase in a sentence.

Usage notes

은 (eun) is always used after a word (a noun, a noun phrase, or a nominalized verb/adjective in ㅁ form), ending in a consonant. Identical in meaning to 는 (neun) which occurs only after a word ending in a vowel.

  • (topic marker): The topic is what is being talked about in the sentence, it is the main point. This however is different in meaning from the subject which the predicate directly refers to. The topic and subject may be the same in a sentence. For example,
    • 매리는 내 친구다. (Mary-neun nae chingu-da.) — “Mary is my friend.”
    In this case "Mary" is the topic (and the subject) of this sentence and "is my friend" is the predicate. However, in many cases, the subject and topic are different.
    • 이 반은 학생이 똑똑하다. (I ban-eun haksaeng-i ddokddokhada.) — “Speaking of this class, the students are smart.”
    Above, the topic is "This class" while the subject is "the students".
    In cases like this, the topic can often be thought of as a range, or to what extent the sentence is applicable. In the example above, if "speaking of this class" was removed, the sentence would not be limited to "this class", and would talk about all students in general.
  • (Contrast/emphasis marker): 은 (eun), can be placed after most case markers (including 가 (ga), 를 (reul), 에 (e), 에게 (ege), 에서 (eseo), 로 (ro), 과 (gwa)) to show contrast between two or more choices or add emphasis to a word or phrase, depending on the context. If used after 가 (ga) or 를 (reul), the 가 (ga) or 를 (reul) are deleted leaving only 은 (eun).
    • 나는 서울에 가고 싶다. (Na-neun Seoul-e ganda.) — “I want to go to Seoul.”
    • 나는 서울에는 가고 싶다. (Na-neun Seoul-e-neun ganda.) — “I want to go to Seoul (and not Busan).” or “I want to (especially) go to Seoul.”
    • 나는 존에게 책을 주었다. (Na-neun John-ege chaeg-eul jueotta.) — “I gave John a book.”
    • 나는 존에게는 책을 주었다. (Na-neun John-ege-neun chaeg-eul juotta.) — “I gave John (and not Fred) a book.” or “I gave (especially) John a book.”
    In cases where there are two cases of either 는 (neun) or 은 (eun) in a sentence it is assumed that the first usage refers to the topic while the second usage refers to some contrast or emphasis.

Synonyms

  • (used after a word ending in a vowel) 는 (neun)

See also

  • 이 (i), 가 (ga)

Etymology 3

Korean reading of various Chinese characters.

Noun

은 • (eun) (hanja 銀)

  1. silver

Derived terms

  • 백은 (白銀, baegeun)
Retrieved from "https://en.wiktionary.org/w/index.php?title=은&oldid=49268915"

을 - Wiktionary

Korean

으윽윾윿은읁읂
읃을읅읆읇읈읉
읊읋음읍읎읏읐
응읒읓읔읕읖읗
유 ←→ 의

Etymology 1

Particle

을 • (-eul)

  1. particle indicating the direct object of a verb
Usage notes
  • Like other Korean particles, 을 (eul) is a postposition. It marks the preceding noun as the direct object of the following verb.
  • 을 (-eul) only comes after a word ending in a consonant. If the modified word ends in a vowel, 를 (-reul) is used instead:
  • 책 + 을 => 책을
    chaek + eul => chaeg-eul
  • 사과 + 를 => 사과를
    sagwa + reul => sagwa-reul
  • 을 (-eul) is optional if it can be inferred that the noun is the direct object (as opposed to the subject).

If the noun is the main topic of the sentence and it can be inferred that the noun is the direct object (as opposed to the subject), 은 (-eun) may be used instead, though in many cases 은 (-eun) might be interpreted as a contrast.

See also
  • 이 (i)
  • 은 (eun)

Etymology 2

Suffix

—을 • (--eul)

  • alternative form of ㄹ (-l), used after consonants
  1. An ending of a word that makes the preceding statement function as an adnominal phrase.
    이 버섯들은 먹을 수 있다.
    I beoseotdeureun meogeul su itda.
    These mushrooms are edible.
  2. that will; who will (An ending of a word that makes the preceding statement function as an adnominal phrase and indicates assumption, prearrangement, intention, possibility, etc.)
Retrieved from "https://en.wiktionary.org/w/index.php?title=을&oldid=49994984"

지 - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology 1

지직짂짃진짅짆
짇질짉짊짋짌짍
짎짏짐집짒짓짔
징짖짗짘짙짚짛
즤 ←→ 짜

Syllable

지 • (ji)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ㅈ and ㅣ.

Etymology 2

First attested in the Seokbo sangjeol (釋譜詳節 / 석보상절), 1447, as Middle Korean 디.

Noun

지 • (ji)

  1. since (somebody) last (did something); from the time that
Usage notes

In the sense of "since", 지 indicates a period of time. The verb or adjective immediately preceding 지 must be in the attributive form (-ㄴ). This attributive form may follow the adverbs 못 or 안. Although 지 means ‘since’ as used with durations, usage differs from English ‘since’ insofar as the Korean verb preceding 지 should be negated where the English clause containing ‘since’ would not, and vice versa: Compare negative Korean “… 안 한 지” with positive English “since (somebody) last …ed”.

The 지 sentence must end in the combination of a timespan (for example 2주) or a question verb asking “how long” (for example 몇 주) and a verb such as 되다 or 지나다.

Examples:

  • 어머니를 뵌 지 벌써 오래되었다.
    “It has already been a long time since I've seen my mother.”
  • 머리를 못/안 감은 지 2주쯤 되면 느낌이 어떨까요?
    “What will it feel like when (somebody hasn't) washed (their) hair for two weeks?”

Compare 만 and 부터 which differ from 지 in usage.

Etymology 3

Of native Korean origin.

Suffix

—지 • (-ji)

  1. verb suffix used to seek affirmation, or to give the listener(s) an opportunity to express whether they can follow or not, to agree, or to confirm what is said:
    “어렵지?”
    “eoryeopji?”
    It's difficult, isn't it?
    “한국말을 이해하시지?”
    “han-gungmareul ihaehasiji?”
    You understand Korean, right?
  2. verb suffix a speaker uses to recommend a change in the listener's behaviour, or to soften imperatives:
    (To a hasty eater)
    “천천히 먹지”
    “cheoncheonhi meokji”
    Eat slowly.
Derived terms
  • 죠 (jyo)

Etymology 4

Of native Korean origin.

Suffix

—지 • (-ji)

  1. suffix either marking the verb that is negated by following 못하다/않다, or marking what a following 말다 says not to do:
    “담배를 피우지 맙시다.”
    “dambaereul piuji mapsida.”
    Let's not smoke cigarettes.
    • 지 can optionally receive markers such as 는, 가, and 를:
      많지가 않아요
      manchiga anayo
      … is not much
    • 지 is not used to form a negative copula:
      “다가 아니다”
      “daga anida”
      … is not all
    • 지 is used when saying some action was a mistake (for example when regretting something), and when thinking about better not doing something:
      “… 서울에 오지 말 걸 그랬네요.”
      “… Seoure oji mal geol geuraenneyo.”
      “… shouldn't have come to Seoul.”
      “… 서울에 가지 말까 생각도 해 봤지만 ….”
      “… Seoure gaji malkka saenggakdo hae bwatjiman ….”
      “… have/has been thinking about not going to Seoul, but …”
      But:
      “서울에 안 가는 게 나을 것 같지요.”
      “Seoure an ganeun ge na-eul geot gatjiyo.”
      Not going to Seoul seems better; don't you think so?

See also

  • -ㄴ지 (-nji) / -는지 (neunji) / -ㄹ지 (-lji) / -던지 (-deonji)

Etymology 5

Colloquial variant of 저 (jeo, “oneself”)

Pronoun

지 • (ji)

  1. (colloquial) oneself; the aforementioned one
    지는 할 거 다 하고 살면서 맨날 나보고 뭐라 그래.
    Jineun hal geo da hago salmyeonseo maennal nabogo mwora geurae.
    He does all what he wants and he tells me off everyday!

Synonyms

  • 자기 (jagi)

Etymology 6

Korean reading of various Chinese characters.

Noun

지 • (ji, McCune-Reischauer: chi, Yale: ci) (hanja 篪)

  1. an ancient bamboo flute with five finger holes; used in aak
Retrieved from "https://en.wiktionary.org/w/index.php?title=지&oldid=49268826"

진 - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology 1

지직짂짃진짅짆

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[t͡ɕin]
  • Phonetic Hangul[진]
Revised Romanization? jin
Revised Romanization (translit.)? jin
McCune–Reischauer? chin

Syllable

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ㅈ, ㅣ, and ㄴ.

Etymology 2

Korean reading of various Chinese characters.

Syllable

진 (jin)

  1. 進: progression
    (eumhun reading: 나아갈 진 (naagal jin))
  2. 鎭: pressing
    (eumhun reading: 진압할 진 (jinaphal jin))
  3. 眞: true
    (eumhun reading: 참 진 (cham jin))
  4. 振: stirring up
    (eumhun reading: 떨칠 진 (tteolchil jin))
  5. 晉: progression
    (eumhun reading: 나아갈 진 (naagal jin))
  6. 珍: jewel
    (eumhun reading: 보배 진 (bobae jin))
  7. 辰: dragon as the 5th earthly branch; the bearing 120º (between ESE and SE); the third lunar month; & the time from 7 to 9 am; also a name of various early Korean states
    (eumhun reading: 별 진 (byeol jin))
  8. 津: ferry
    (eumhun reading: 나루 진 (naru jin))
  9. 陳: bestowal
    (eumhun reading: 베풀 진 (bepul jin))
  10. 診: diagnosing
    (eumhun reading: 볼 진 (bol jin))
  11. 震: lightning
    (eumhun reading: 벼락 진 (byeorak jin))
  12. 陣: forming ranks
    (eumhun reading: 진 칠 진 (jin chil jin))
  13. 秦: a kind of rice
    (eumhun reading: 벼 이름 진 (byeo ireum jin))
  14. 塵: mote
    (eumhun reading: 티끌 진 (tikkeul jin))
  15. 盡: finishing
    (eumhun reading: 다할 진 (dahal jin))
  16. 軫: 수레 튀덕 나무
  17. 璡: jade-like stone
    (eumhun reading: 옥돌 진 (okdol jin))
  18. 瑨: beautiful stone
    (eumhun reading: 아름다운 돌 진 (areumdaun dol jin))
  19. 榛: hazel
    (eumhun reading: 개암나무 진 (gaeamnamu jin))
  20. 賑: rescue
    (eumhun reading: 구휼할 진 (guhyulhal jin))
  21. 縉: insertion
    (eumhun reading: 꽂을 진 (kkojeul jin))
  22. 溱: multitude
    (eumhun reading: 많을 진 (maneul jin))
  23. 疹: measles
    (eumhun reading: 홍역 진 (hong-yeok jin))
  24. 嗔: wrath
    (eumhun reading: 성낼 진 (seongnael jin))
  25. 瞋: glaring
    (eumhun reading: 부릅뜰 진 (bureuptteul jin))
  26. 唇: surprise
    (eumhun reading: 놀랄 진 (nollal jin))
  27. 搢: insertion
    (eumhun reading: 꽂을 진 (kkojeul jin))
  28. 晋: progression
    (eumhun reading: 나아 진 (naa jin))
  29. 桭: eaves
    (eumhun reading: 처마 진 (cheoma jin))
  30. 殄: ending
    (eumhun reading: 다할 진 (dahal jin))
  31. 畛: paddy path
    (eumhun reading: 두렁길 진 (dureonggil jin))
  32. 縝: hemp yarn
    (eumhun reading: 삼실 진 (samsil jin))
  33. 臻: arriving
    (eumhun reading: 이를 진 (ireul jin))
  34. 蔯: a kind of chrysanthemum
    (eumhun reading: 더위지기 진 (deowijigi jin))
  35. 袗: unhemmed garments
    (eumhun reading: 홑옷 진 (hotot jin))

Etymology 3

Hangulization of various English words.

Noun

진 • (jin)

  1. jeans, or jean fabric
  2. gin

Etymology 4

Determinative form of various Korean verbs and adjectives.

Adjective

진 • (jin) (determiner of 질다)

  1. wet, watery

Verb

진 • (jin) (past-tense determiner of 지다)

  1. having lost.

츼 ←→ 카

Syllable

치 • (chi)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ㅊ and ㅣ.

Etymology 2

Korean reading of various Chinese characters.

Noun 1

치 • (chi) (hanja 齒)

  1. tooth or teeth
Synonyms
  • 이 (i)

Noun 2

치 • (chi) (hanja 寸)

  1. (unit of measure) A chi or Korean inch, a unit of length equivalent to about 3.03 cm.
Synonyms
  • 촌 (chon)

Etymology 3

Suffix

—치 • (-chi) (hanja 値)

  1. value.
    계산치. 측정치.
Synonyms
  • 값 (gap)

Etymology 4

Contraction.

Suffix

—치 • (-chi)

  1. contraction of 하지.
    중요치 않다.

해 - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology 1

해핵핶핷핸핹핺
핻핼핽핾핿햀햁
햂햃햄햅햆햇했
행햊햋햌햍햎햏
하 ←→ 햐

Syllable

해 • (hae)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ㅎ and ㅐ.

Etymology 2

First attested in the Yongbi eocheonga (龍飛御天歌 / 용비어천가), 1447, as Middle Korean ᄒᆡ (hoy).

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[he̞]
  • Phonetic Hangul[해]
Revised Romanization? hae
Revised Romanization (translit.)? hae
McCune–Reischauer? hae
Yale Romanization? hay

Noun

해 • (hae)

  1. the Sun
    Synonym: 태양 (taeyang)
    Antonym: 달 (dal)
    • 해가 서쪽에서 뜨다.
      Haega seojjogeseo tteuda.
      (saying) The Sun rises from the west; i.e. something impossible.
  2. sunlight, sunbeam
    • 이 방은 해가 잘 든다.
      I bang-eun haega jal deunda.
      This room is well-illuminated by sunlight.
  3. daytime
    Synonyms: 날 (nal), 낮 (nat)
  4. year
    Synonym: 년 (nyeon)
Derived terms
Derived terms
  • 해바라기 (haebaragi, “sunflower”)
  • 햅쌀 (haepssal, “rice of the year”)
  • 햇것 (haetgeot, “produce of the year”)
  • 햇귀 (haetgwi, “sunbeam (literally, "sun's ear")”)
  • 햇무리 (haenmuri, “solar halo”)
  • 햇볕 (haetbyeot, “sunshine (mainly in terms of heat)”)
  • 햇빛 (haetbit, “sunlight”)
  • 햇살 (haetsal, “sunbeam”)

Prefix

해— • (hae-)

  1. white
Derived terms
Derived terms
  • 해맑다 (haemakda, “to be white and clean”)

Etymology 3

Sino-Korean word from 害

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[he̞ː]
  • Phonetic Hangul[해]
Revised Romanization? hae
Revised Romanization (translit.)? hae
McCune–Reischauer? hae
Yale Romanization? hāy

Noun

해 • (hae) (hanja 害)

  1. harm, damage, evil, injury
Derived terms
Derived terms
  • 해치다 (haechida)
  • 해코지 (haekoji)

Etymology 4

Sino-Korean word from 海

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[he̞ː]
  • Phonetic Hangul[해]
Revised Romanization? hae
Revised Romanization (translit.)? hae
McCune–Reischauer? hae

Noun

하— (ha-) + —어 (eo).

Pronunciation

Verb

  1. infinitive of 하다 (hada)

화 - Wiktionary

Korean

Etymology 1

화확홖홗환홙홚
홛활홝홞홟홠홡
홢홣홤홥홦홧홨
황홪홫홬홭홮홯
호 ←→ 홰

Syllable

화 • (hwa)

  1. A Hangul syllabic block made up of ㅎ and ㅘ.

Etymology 2

Reading of various Chinese characters.

Pronunciation

  • IPA(key)[ɸwa̠ː]
  • Phonetic Hangul[화]
Revised Romanization? hwa
Revised Romanization (translit.)? hwa
McCune–Reischauer? hwa
Yale Romanization? hwā

Noun

화 • (hwa)

  1. (火) fire (usually used in compounds)
    Synonym: 불 (bul)
  2. (火) anger
    화가 나다 (hwaga nada) — one becomes angry
    그 여자는 왜 화가 났습니까?
    Geu yeojaneun wae hwaga natseumnikka?
    Why was she angry?

Abbreviation

화 • (hwa)

  1. Abbreviation of 화요일 (hwayoil): Tuesday

Syllable

화 (hwa)

  1. 火 - fire, Tuesday
  2. 花 - flower
  3. 華 - China
  4. 話 - talk; episode (in a book, series, etc.)
  5. 畵 - picture
  6. 化 - transformation
  7. 和 - harmony
  8. 靴 - shoe
